ducted by five full-time qualified
pediatricians. Another 14 members of
the Einstein pediatrics faculty, include
ing such men as the noted pediatric
cardiologist Abraham Rudolph, act as
consultants.
Today, in spite of an unusually
high prematurity rate-most of the
mothers are unmarried and many are
under age 16-Lincoln's neonatal
mortality rate has dropped well below
the national average.
Staffing problems such as those
that plagued Lincoln before its affilia-
tion play a major part in infant mortal-
ity. A series of amendments now be-
fore the House of Representatives
would raise the authorization for ma-
ternity and infant care programs by $5
million to a total of $35 million in fis-
cal 1968. The bills would also allow
HEW to experiment with new types of
physician assistants to bring more
comprehensive health care to mothers
and children in low-income areas. And
they would provide some $10 million
to set up ten university-affiliated dem-
onstration projects that would train
pediatric and obstetric assistants.
Manpower Shortage Foreseen
Will there be enough manpower to
handle the load when all infants get
the facilities they need? The answer
seems to be no, based on the ratio of
medical practitioners caring for chil-
dren, including both general practi-

falling constantly since 1940, and pre-
dictions are that it will reach an all-
time low of 68 doctors per 100,000
children in 1980, when there will be
an estimated 75 million children under
age 15 in this country.
